Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Sara Linker of the University of Miami to conduct a research project in Biology during the summer of 2013 at the Center for iPS Cell Research and Application at Kyoto University in Kyoto, Japan. The project title is "Evaluating the Transgenic Applications of Mobile DNA in Human Pluripotent Stem cells." The host scientist is Dr. Knut Woltjen.

Transgenics, delivering engineered genes stably into a target cell's genome, is a mainstay of functional genomics. For proper function, gene-trap transgenesis requires that an engineered vector integrates into the correct portion of a gene. Despite this requirement current gene-trapping methods proceed with little or no empirical knowledge of integration profiles, thereby limiting the efficiency of the approach. This study bioinformatically evaluates the integration profiles of transposons which are commonly used for integration and then couple each transposon with the best possible gene-trap. The successful completion of this project will result in a system of transgenic tools that are highly efficient for integration in human stem cells.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the EAPSI Fellow will present a summary of research done at both the home and host institutions in order to foster collaboration between labs which have shared goals, but no previous partnership. The finalized research will be presented at scientific meetings both in the U.S. and Japan, and will be published for broad dissemination of knowledge. Data from the research will also be used to instruct students from underserved populations in Miami who participate in the University of Miami's J.J. Vance Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of stem cells is crucial to testing biological paradigms on the human system, though there are many ethical and biological issues that surround their use. Induced pluripotent stems cells (iPSCs) have recently been developed to circumvent many of these issues. IPSCs are cells that have been taken from differentiated donor cells and programmed to revert these cells to a stem cell-like state. These iPSCs can then be differentiated into almost any cell of the body. In order to revert differentiated cells into iPSCs, cells are exposed to a set of four transcription factors: OCT4, SOX2, KLF4, and MYC. These four factors have been used in labs worldwide to induce pluripotency, however different labs use different isoforms of the transcription factors. Dr. Woltjen’s team at the Center for iPSC Research and Application in Kyoto identified that these different isoforms result in widely varied dynamics of the reprogramming process. For example, they found that when using one isoform of KLF4 the cells divided rapidly but most did not result in iPSCs, while the other isoform resulted in a slow process but with many cells that completed reprogramming to become iPSCs. These results suggested that there were underlying differences caused by the choice of isoform. To understand the transcriptional dynamics of the reprogramming process, Dr. Woltjen’s lab extracted RNA from cells at multiple time points through the differentiation process. This was repeated for constructs containing different isoforms of the transcription factors. The RNA was analyzed using microarray and were then compared across time and across construct type.

As expected, all cells had similar expression profiles at early time points after transfection with the constructs. Over time, however, differences began to emerge. Overall, the constructs that contained similar isoforms had similar expression patterns at each time point, while the constructs containing different isoforms had markedly different profiles. The most striking finding was that the genes that were differentially expressed between the two groups were correlated with endothelial development, specifically keratin development. This finding suggested that a specific isoform of KLF4 biases cells for passing through a keratin-like state on the path to pluripotency. These findings indicate that constructs used in the field to generate iPSCs are not as similar as had been previously thought. This can have an effect on both the replication of results in the field of iPSCs as well as interpretation of future findings.

In conclusion, although most labs use the same four transcription factors for induction of pluripotency, minor differences in these factors contribute to differences in the reprogramming process. These results suggest that there are multiple pathways that a cell can transition through to arrive in a pluripotent state and supports future work into determining what effects each transition has on the final cell state.
